sen.j: 運慶（うんけい、- 貞応2年12月11日 (旧暦)（1224年1月3日））は、平安時代末期、鎌倉時代初期に活動した仏師。
sen.e: Unkei (unknown birth date - January 3, 1224 (by the lunar calendar)) was a sculptor of Buddhist statues who was actively engaged in his career from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

sen.e: Unkei was a child of Kokei, a Buddhist statue sculptor from Nara, who performed his craft mainly at the Kofuku-ji Temple in Nara City.

sen.j: 長男湛慶が承安3年（1173年）生まれであることが、京都市・妙法院蓮華王院本堂（三十三間堂）本尊の台座銘から知られ、運慶は12世紀半ば頃の生まれと推測される。

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）に平家の兵火により、奈良の東大寺・興福寺が焼亡する。
sen.e: In 1180, the Todai-ji Temple and the Kofuku-ji Temple in Nara burned to the ground due to the fire started by Heike in battle.

sen.j: 興福寺の再興造像は、円派、院派と呼ばれる京都仏師と、康慶・運慶らの属する奈良仏師とが分担した。
sen.e: Statue restoration work at the Kofuku-ji Temple was shared between Kyoto-based Buddhist statue sculptors called EN-pa and IN-pa (EN school and IN school), and Nara-based Buddhist statue sculptors such as Kokei and Unkei.

sen.j: 当時の中央造仏界での勢力にしたがい、円派・院派のほうが金堂・講堂のような主要堂塔の造像を担当することとなり、奈良仏師では康慶が南円堂の本尊を担当し、本家筋にあたる成朝は食堂の本尊を担当することとなった。
sen.e: According to the power balance within the central Buddhist image creation field, EN-pa and IN-pa created statues for major halls and towers such as Kon-do and Ko-do, Nara-based Buddhist statue sculptor Kokei created the main statue for Nanen-do, and Seicho, another Nara-based Buddhist statue sculptor of Imperial lineage was in charge of the main statue for Shoku-do.

The work was divided according to influence in the Buddhist art field, with the En-pa and In-pa creating statues for major halls and towers such as the Kon-do (Main Hall) and Ko-do (Lecture Hall), Nara-based Buddhist statue sculptor Kokei creating the main statue for the Nanen-do (South Octagonal Hall), and Seicho, another Nara-based Buddhist statue sculptor of Imperial lineage, in charge of the main statue for the Shoku-do (Dining Hall).

sen.j: 成朝は、なぜか食堂本尊の造像に専念せず、文治元年（1185年）に源頼朝の勝長寿院本尊を造るため鎌倉に下向した。
sen.e: Seicho however for some reason did not dedicate himself in creation of the main statue for Shoku-do, and headed down to Kamakura to create the main statue of worship at the Shochoju-in Temple for MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.

sen.e: Meanwhile, after completing the Shakanyorai (Gotama Siddhattha) statue, which was the main statue at the Saikon-do of the Kofuku-ji Temple in January, 1186, Unkei started to take assignments associated with the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) as if he followed Seicho's move.

sen.j: 願成就院の仏像は、平安時代後期の仏像とは隔絶した、めざましい作風を示している。
sen.e: The style of statues at the Ganjoju-in Temple was truly striking and outstanding, completely differing from Buddhist statues carved in the late Heian period.

sen.j: 平安後期に都でもてはやされた定朝様（じょうちょうよう）の仏像は、浅く平行して流れる衣文、円満で穏やかな表情、浅い肉付けに特色があり、平安貴族の好みを反映したものであったが、分業制で同じような仏像を量産した結果、無個性でマンネリ化した作風に陥っていた。
sen.e: Buddhist statues of the Jocho-yo (Jocho style), which was hugely popular in the Capital city in the late Heian period, were characterized by smooth wrinkles of clothes that were carved shallow and parallel, facial expressions that looked satisfied and calm, and only little amplification of forms, representing the taste of Heian aristocrats; however, as a result of mass production of similar Buddhist statues through division of labor, the statues were no longer unique and always looked the same.

sen.e: Meanwhile, Unkei style was characterized by masculine facial expressions, wide variety of expression of clothes texture, and powerful and heavy bodies, and this kind of style seemed to have matched the taste of eastern bushi (warriors).

sen.e: In 1196, together with Kokei, Kaikei, and Jokaku, Unkei participated in a major assignment to create the Ryowakiji statues to be placed on both sides of the Daibutsu (Big Buddha) and the Shitenno (Four Heavenly Kings) statues for the Todai-ji Temple, but these statues do not exist any more as they were destroyed with the Daibutsu-den (hall) in a fire.
